qas.question: What is the name of the first wave of neoclassicism in France?
France's second phase of neoclassic is known as what?
What architect typifies the first style of neoclassical in England?
Structure of whom characterize England's second phase of neoclassical?
Who styled the court in France for more modern design after 1771?
What style marked the first phase of neoclassicism in continental Europe?
What style was originally a court style and not a Parisien style?
What King brought the Louis XVI style to court?

context: The first phase of neoclassicism in France is expressed in the "<a0_0><b5_0>Louis XVI style<b5_0/><a0_0/>" of architects like Ange-Jacques Gabriel (Petit Trianon, 1762–68); the second phase, in the styles called <a1_0>Directoire and "<b6_0>Empire<b6_0/>"<a1_0/>, might be characterized by Jean Chalgrin's severe astylar Arc de Triomphe (designed in 1806). In England the two phases might be characterized first by the structures of <a2_0>Robert Adam<a2_0/>, the second by those of <a3_0>Sir John Soane<a3_0/>. The interior style in France was initially a Parisian style, the "<b7_0>Goût grec<b7_0/>" ("Greek style") not a court style. Only when the young king acceded to the throne in 1771 did <a4_0>Marie Antoinette<a4_0/>, his fashion-loving Queen, bring the "<b8_0>Louis XVI<b8_0/>" style to court.
